li.title: Finding Exponential Formulas (Tables, Graphs and Language)

conclusion.p: In this lesson we learn about a family of functions called "exponential". Just like linear functions, exponentials have their or own general shapes and basic formulas and numerical patterns.
For instance, linear functions look like lines on a graph.

conclusion.p: While exponential functions bend in a smooth curve. In the figure below the curve is concave up.

But the formula for an exponential function may look like this
The formula can be written in various ways but we begin this lesson with what is called the discrete form.
Finally, when we look at a table of values, linear functions will always have a pattern of adding the same number repeatedly (a positive or negative constant) for constant changes in input.
This leads to the fact that linear functions have constant rate of change (slope).

In turn, exponentials will have a pattern of repeated multiplication by the same number called a growth factor usually denoted by the variable b. If b \gt 1 we have exponential growth while if 0 \lt b \lt 1 we have exponential decay.
This leads to the fact that exponential functions have constant percent change where mutliplying is interpreted as a percent change.
For example, there is a big difference between adding 1.25 repeatedly versus multiplying by 1.25 repeatedly.

conclusion.p: Consider the interactive graph you made of the exponential function. Notice that as you move to the left along the x-axis, the graph tends to drop closer and closer to the x-axis.
In fact, the farther you go to the left, the closer the graph gets to the x-axis. In truth the graph will never reach the x-axis.
The x-axis is the horizontal line y = 0 and the graph is tending towards y = 0 as the inputs move to the left.
We say that the x-axis is a horizontal asymptote with equation y = 0. It means that the graph is getting closer and closer to the x-axis in at least one direction.
